In 411 he defeated the Athenian fleet near Oropus and caused Euboea to defect.a

After the battle of Cynossema he went to the Hellespont under the orders of the nauarch Mindares, but was shipwrecked near Athos.bc With the ships that were saved he defeated the Athenian Thymochares.d
In 431 BC, as part of the third Spartan embassy, he presented the
ultimatum to Athens before the outbreak of the Peloponnesian War.

Son of King Archidamos II and Eupolia
Half-brother of King Agis II and Teleutias
Agesilaos was born in 444/3 and about 402 married Kleora (cf. Aristomenidas) who bore him three children, Archidamos, Eupolia, and Prolyta.mC
When, after the death of Agis II in the summer of 399, Agis’ son Leotychidas was disqualified, Agesilaos—particularly through the influence of his boyhood friend Lysander—received the throne.Cujg
Likewise, through the efforts of Lysander was Agesilaos appointed the commander in the war against Persia. He sailed in the spring of 396 from Aulis to Ephesus.kCh
He conducted the war in Asia Minor until the summer of 394, when he was recalled because of political developments in Greece.Cxwlva
In thirty days he marched to Boeotia, where he established a camp at Chaeroneia on the 25th or 26th of August 394 and soon thereafter defeated the enemies of Sparta in the battle of Coronea.Cm
To heal the wound that he had received in the battle he took himself to Delphi and from there travelled home on a ship.Cx
In 391 he laid waste to Argos and continued on to Corinth where he had the long walls of Lechaeum torn down.Cy
In the summer of the next year <390> he was active at the IsthmusCop. There he fought on behalf of the Achaeans against the Acarnanians.Cp
At the peace conference in Sparta in 387/6 he forced through the recognition of the King’s Peace on the part of the Thebans and the dissolution of the just founded city Corinth-Argos.Cz
In the fall of 381 he struck against Phlius, which he took after a siege of twenty months.C

In similar fashion he participated in the great struggle between Thebes and Sparta. He undertook two operations to Boeotia in 378/7. A wound, which he received on the march back, kept him from the theater of war for a long time,Cb so he acted all the more energetically against Thebes in 371 at the congress at Sparta, when he excluded the Thebans from the common peace.Cq

After the catastrophe at Leuctra he campaigned with the full army against Mantinea, but had to withdraw to Sparta at the approach of the Thebans.C By his careful handling he saved the country from the invasion of Epaminondas in the winter of 370/69.r
Around 364 he travelled to Asia to earn money for Sparta and fought there together with the Athenian Timotheos for the interests of Ariobarzanes.Af
In 362 we find the king back in Greece, where shortly before the battle of Mantinea he saved Sparta a second time from a Theban invasion.Csc

In 361 he went to Egypt to enter the service of Tachos, to earn money for Sparta as the leader of a mercenary band. When he was demoted by Tachos he went over to Nectanebo and did important service for him. Therefore, when he prepared his return home, he was loaded with rich gifts. He never reached his homeland, but died in the winter of 360/59 between Egypt and Cyrene in the “harbor of Menelaos.” His body was brought back to Sparta.tde

Poralla 14; Diodorus XIV 89a, XV 22,2, 23,2b; Pausanias III 5.7c, VIII 8.7-9(f); Xenophon Hellenica IV 2.9d, 7.2-7e; V 2.3-7f, 3.8-9, 18-9g (Agesipolis and Agesilaus have been confused in Suidas s. v. Ἆγις and Diodorus XIV 97.5.)
When his father went into exile after the battle of Haliartos in 395, Agesipolis ascended the throneac. Since he was still a minor, he had a regent, Aristodemusd.

In 388/7 he led a successful campaign against the Argivese. In 385/4 he forced Mantinea to disband the league it had formedf. In the year 381 he invaded Chalcidice with a great army, but died shortly after the capture of Torone in Summer 380.
His body was brought to Spartabg.
Poralla 15; Plutarch Agis 3a, Diodorus XV 60.4b; Pausanias I 13.4, III 6.2c
After the death of his father in 371 Agesipolis succeeded to the throne, but he died after about a one-year reign and left no childrenabc.
Son of Kleombrotos (1) II and Chilonis (2)
He was young enough in 241 BC to be carried by a parent. He died before 219 BC.
He was appointed king as a child after the death of Kleomenes (1) III,
219 BCab His uncle, Kleomenes (2), was regenta. He was expelled by Lykourgos (1)c. As an envoy to Rome, ca. 184 BC, he was killed by piratesb.

In the following winter he led reinforcements to the aid of the
Epidaurians who were hard pressed by the Argives.

A Spartiate who was sent by Agesilaos II to Memphis during the time when Plato was travelling in Egypt. We do not have an exact date for Plato’s Egyptian stay. Plato left Athens after the death of Socrates and travelled through the Peloponnesus, to Egypt and Cyrene. In 388 he had already visited Syracuse again. The trip of Agetoridas then, if it is at all historical, must fall in the period 399-388.

He was the eponymous king of the house of the Agids—obviously a mythical personab.
During his reign (1061-1030/29) the helots were subjugatedc. He is also made the ultimate ancestor of the mythical Amphiklesd.

Poralla 26; Thucydides III 89a, IV 2. 6b, V 19, 24c, 54d, 57-60 & 63-75e, 83f, VII 19 & 27g, VIII 3h, 5-11 & 70-71i; Plutarch Agesilaus 1. 3j; Diodorus XI 48k, XII 35.4l, 78-79m, XIII 107n; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.33-35o, II 2. 7-13p, II 3.3q, III 2.22-29 & 3.1r; Pausanias III 8.3-5s, VI 2.3t; IDelos 87 (IG V 1. 1564); Justin V 2.5; Nepos Agesilaus 1; Athenaeus XII 535b, 543b
King from the house of the Eurypontids

After the death of Archidamos Agis assumed the throne in 427/6k. In the years 426 and 425 he twice led the army into Attica.ab With his fellow king Pleistoanax in 421 he underwrote the peace of Nicias and the alliance with Athens.c

In 419 he marched with the assembled army to Leuctra, but turned back to Sparta without accomplishing anything.d In the next summer he campaigned twice against the Argives and besieged them because of their alliance with Mantineaem. In a third campaign at the beginning of the winter of 417 he caused the newly built walls of Argos to be torn downf.

In spring 413 Agis invaded Attica and seized Decelea, where he remained as commanderg. From here he undertook in the following winter a campaign against the Oitaians and the Achaeans living in Phthiotis, to reestablish the influence of the Spartans on the Malean Gulfh. From Decelea Agis supported all rebellions against Athens in Asia Minor and along the Hellespont and tried several times to take the cityio. He did not take part in the siege of Athens in 405/4nq, although he did offer his good ofices to the Atheniansp.
After the fall of Athens he led a long campaign against Elist and visited Delphi. On his return trip he fell sick and died soon after his arrival in Sparta, probably in the summer of 399lrs.

He succeeded his father in 338 and ruled for nine yearsd. In 333, as leader of the opposition to Alexander the Great, Agis travelled to Siphnos to meet Pharnabazos and Autophradates, the commanders of the Persian fleet; he obtained money and troops from them. Then he travelled to Halicarnassos where he led some of the survivors of the Greek mercenaries from the battle of Issos to Cretece. After he returned to Sparta he besieged Megalopolis, but in a battle fought there against Antipater, he was killed (in 331 or 330)fg.
He and his brothers (Eupylidas, Chairis, Lykos, Alexon, Eraton, and Gylippos) fell at Messene sometime after 369.

body.p: Plutarch Agis passim, Cleomenes 1-3, Agesilaus 40.5; comparatio Agis Cleomenes Ti. Gracchus C. Gracchus, Aratus 31.1; Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 216d; Lamprias catalogue Number 9; Cicero de officiis II 80; Pausanias II 8.5; III 10.5; VI 2.4; VII 7.3; VIII 8.11, 10.5-8, 27.13-14, 36.6 (Pausanias confuses Agis IV and Archidamos IV); Prometheus VII 1981, pp. 35-42: Agis became king as a child with Agesilaos as his regent.
Son of Eudamidas (2) II and Agesistrata
He was the first king of Sparta to attempt to recover her military strength through an increase in the number of citizen-soldiers by cancellation of debt, distribution of land, and enfranchisement.
He was opposed by the wealthy and by Leonidas (1) II, the Agiad king, though a large minority of the fully enfranchised citizen body supported Agis.
With the help of his advisers and supporters, Lysandros (1), Mandrokleidas, and Agesilaos (2), he expelled Leonidas, brought Kleombrotos (1) II to the throne, and passed a bill cancelling debt.

He led an army to aid the Achaean League against the Aetolians, but no engagement was fought. In his absence his opponents gained the upper hand. (Pausanias confuses the actions of the Aetolians and the Spartans under Agis in his reading of Plutarch’s life of Aratus.)
Leonidas II returned from exile and forced Agis to seek sanctuary. Agis was betrayed, tried by the ephors, and executed.
First cousin of C. Pompo(nius) Alkastos (3)c

Campaigned by ship against the Peisistratids in Athens in 511/10 and was defeated and killed by Hippias and the Thessalian cavalry. His grave memorial was located in the Attic deme Alopeke.

Young woman’s name in a chorus by Alcman. Four of the singers lived with her.
A Laconian, who fell in war; an inscription of about the year 400 found
He was a victor at Olympia in the pentathlon and died shortly after the victory. He had a portrait statue in Amyclae
He found his death in the field.
Agatharchides of Cnidus mentioned him in the 30th book of his Europiaka. Book 27 has events of 244/3 BC. Book 31 has events of ca. 217 BC. Hairesippos, then, falls between these years.
Subject of an honorary decree by a city other than Sparta
Owner of a slave named Clodia

As a member of the college of ephors he concluded the peace of Nikias
and the alliance with Athens in spring 421.
Gravemarker: nine years old at death
Presbys of ephors in the year of C. Ju(lius) Lysikrates (1)a, AD 152/3

Naopoios in Delphi under the archon Demochares 338/7 and Kaphis
He opposed the decree to relieve the survivors of the battle of Megalopolis, 331 BC, of ignominya.
He commanded the forces of Acragas in Sicily, ca. 314, against Agathokles, but he was stripped of his command and forced to return to Spartaa.
He predeceased his father (who died in 309 BC).b

Athenaeus IV 142b; Parthenius 23; Plutarch Agis 3.7a, Pyrrhus 26.18b, 28.4-7c, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 240ef}; Pausanias III 6.6; {VIII 27.11-13, VIII 30.7 by name refers to Akrotatos (1) but in fact refers to Akrotatos (2)}; SIG3 430d (The editor assigns this inscription to Areus <1> and Akrotatos <1>, but the reference to “King” Akrotatos and “Queen” Chilonis seems to me rather to refer to this Akrotatos.)

Supposedly he committed adultery with the wife of his great uncle, Kleonymos (1), shaming him into leaving Spartab, a story which overlies the intense and bitter rivalry between the families of Areus I and Kleonymos.
He was a young man during Pyrrhus’ invasion of Laconia, 272 BC, but he took part in the fightingc.
He led the Lacedaemonian army to Megalopolis and was killed there, ca. 262 BC, by Aristodemos, the tyranta.

As phrouarch an Alexandros handed over the fortified places of Aeolis to the Spartan commander Thibron. The time is established through the mention of the flute player Thersandros who is appropriate only to the second Asian campaign of Thibron. That Alexandros was Lacedaemonian is probable.

body.p: Killed in a war against the Parthians (during the reign of either M. Aurelius or Caracalla—preferred by Spawforth, ABSA 79, 267-9) at the age of thirty; a relief shows him armed with spear, sword, and shield
Son of Iphikratidas and Alexippa; he is supposed to have fallen with his brothers Eupylidas, Eraton, Chairis, Lykos, Agis, and Gylippos before Messene

Mother of Pausanias and so also the mother of Nikomedes and wife of Kleombrotos. The different forms of the name most likely refer back to one form with 9 or 9. She is supposed to have brought a brick when her son Pausanias was in the temple of Athena Chalkioikos to wall him up.
Poralla 56; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 2.7, IV 4.4; FGrH (Apollodorus Chronika) II 244 (86/7)
Son of Teleklos and father of Polydoros.
The chronographers made him an older contemporary of Theopompos and concluded that the First Messenian War began under him. His reign was supposed to have been 32 years long, 785/4-754/3.

Son of the ephor Sthenlaidas, led an army in 412 to king Agis II at Decelea. He was supposed to sail a fleet to Chios but he was repulsed by the Athenians at the Peiraeus and in the following battle was killed.
A Lacedaemonian murdered by the pro-Aetolian faction in Sparta
Nomophylax in the year of Me(mmius) — (4)
SEG XI 844)]d; SEG XI 499e, 803f; IOlymp 238g; Orthia 330, 63h
Twice periodonikes and victor in many contestsbcf, dedication at Olympia for victory, ca. AD 221 and 225g, “best of the Greeks”bcf

Philocaesar, patriot, high priest of the emperorsabf, presbys of bideoi and subject of an honorary decree for his favors to his countryb; gymnasiarch and subject of an honorary decree for his acts as gymnasiarchf; [bideos]d; agoranomose
[2a] He is also to be recognized in the patronymic Alkandrida of P. Aelius Damocratidas in IG V 1. 305 = Bourguet, 130-32, no. 44 and in the following honorary inscriptions (all Severan)
[e] A. M.Woodward ABSA 26, 1923-25, 211-12 no. 10 with facsimile (XI 802)

[f] The same [?] should be postulated as father of P. Aelius Damocratidas in IG V 1. 655 (emended by L. Robert, REA 31, 1929, 13-18 and supplemented with two fragments by A. M. Woodward, ABSA 29, 1927-28, 41-43 no 65 with facsimile [XI 831], Spawforth, ABSA 79, 1984, 273

Remarks: Bradford distinguishes [1. 2f] [= p. 26 (2) from the Alcandridas of [2a-e] [= p. 27 (6)] regarding the latter as th grandfather of the former, whom he identifies with P. Aelius Alcandridas (III), son of Damocratidas, the prominent Spartan athlete and magistrate of the 1st half of the 3rd c. AD. This is rejected by A. J. S. Spawforth ABSA 80, 1985, 246, 247 n. 147, because he dates [1] in the 3rd quarter of the 2nd c. AD. He considers [1. 2a-e] as P. Aelius Alcandridas (II), the grandfather of P. Aelius Alcandridas (III). Settipani, 496 places his lifetime from AD 130 to after AD 155/65.
For the board of agranomoi in [1] see A. S. Bradford Chiron 10, 1980, 416 n. 33 and N. M. Kennell ZPE 85, 1991, 135n. 15.

Perhaps s. P. Aelius Nicandridas (LAC 16) and probably grands. P. Aelius Alcandridas (I) (LAC 5), presumably h. Pompeia Polla (I) (LAC 613) by whom f. P. Aelius Damocrates (LAC 9), grandf. P. Aelius Alcandridas (III) (LAC 7), perhaps also natural grandf. Ti. Claudius Aelius Partolaus (II) also known as Damocratidas (LAC 251); cf. stemmata in A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 246 tab. 6 (Aelii Alcandridas and Settipani, 496 (the most important families of Roman Sparta); see infra, Appendix, Stemmata I and II.
Brother of Claudia Elpis (1) he kai Kallistonike
He and his sister paid for a memorial to their mother.
Rizakis 5; SEG XI 550; A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 247 (cf. SEG 35, 1985, 328) [AD 140s]
Enseito[s] in the year of [C. Julius Eudamos <6>], AD 139/40-ca. 142
Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #3, plate 72a SEG 48, 1998, 457, l. 6;
Gerousias [for the second or more time] in the year of Nike[phoros h]o [Markou].

“Remarks: The date of the first is based on prosopographical considerations (Woodward loc. cit and A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 210-11 n. 69). Which leads A. M. Woodward to restore the lost name of the eponymous official by analogy with IG V 1. 63 ll. 16-17, a catalogue of ephors in the term of C. Julius Eudamos, A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 27 convincingly restores [Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος)] Ἀλκ[ανδ]ρίδας β[ουαγός] in [1. 1.16]. If this restoration is correct, prosopographically he is the earliest known and otherwise unattested member of this family with Roman citizenship, hence P. Aelius Alcandridas (1). Considering the chronological evidence of this inscription, it is most likely that he had become a Roman citizen through a personal grant of Hadrian on the occasion of one of the emperor’s two visits at Sparta (in AD 124/5 and 128/9). Cf. W. Weber, Untersuchungen zur Geschichte des Kaisers Hadrianus (Leipzig 1907)188-89 n. 671. 211 ns. 744-45; H. Box JRS 21 1931, 201; Chrimes Ancient Sparta 465; Halfmann Itinera principum, 137, 192; Cartledge and Spawforth 108. This would mean that Alcandridas was already of advanced age when ensitos.

“An unpublished inscription discussed in Steinhauer Eurykles testifies that C. Julius Eurykles Herculanus (LAC 462, ARC 105) died in the patronomate of (C. Julius) Nicephoros son of Marcus attested in [2], which should be dated to ca. AD 136/7, see G. Steinhauer, ABSA 93, 1998, 431 n 9. This date allows the identification of P. Aelius Alcandridas in [2] with the homonymous person in [1].

“For the nature of the post and title of bouagos [1(?), 2] in the Spartan agoge of the Roman imperial period see Cartledge and Spawforth, esp 203-204; Kennell, Institutions, 181-85 and id., Gymnasium esp 41-42, 108-09. Perhaps f. P. Aelius Nikandridas (LAC 16) see stemma in Spawforth, op. cit., 246 tab 6 (Aelii Alcandridae); see infra, Appendix, Stemma II.”
A youth who was supposed to have wounded the lawgiver Lycurgus

body.p: Poralla 59; Xenophon Hellenica V 4.56-57; Polyaenus II 7
As harmost he lost Oreos in Winter 377/6 and he was condemned for his carelessness in the loss of this important place.
Man(tis) and [hi]erothytes in the year of Aristokratidas (1)a
Subject of an honorary decree for her domestic virtue, the benefactions of her ancestors, and the blameless life she led with her husband for sixty years.c
Father of Endios (who belonged to the college of ephors in 413/2)
SEG XXVII (1977) 135; G. Daux, Études Delphique (BCH supplement 4, Paris, 1977) 51-57 (photo)
Dedication to Apollo at Delphi, 525-500 BC?
Livy XXXIX 35.6-37.21; Pausanias VII 9.2-4; Polybius XXII 1.9, 11.7-12.4; XXIII 4.3
A Lacedaemonian of great distinction who was exiled by Nabis and restored by the Achaean League
He was an envoy to the Romans in 184 BC, during which mission he denounced the Achaeans.
Father of the Spartiate Agetos (the friend of the king Ariston)
He was supposed to relieve Mytilene in the spring of 427, but he delayed so much on the trip, that at Delos the news reached him of the fall of Mytilene.

After a few voyages here and there along the coast of Asia Minor, he met a superior Athenian force and fled back to the Peloponnesusad. From Cyllene (where Brasidas was his military adviser) he sailed to Corcyra in the summer of 427.
After an indecisive sea battle he escaped from the Athenian fleet over the Isthmus of Leukasb.
In 426 Alkidas went as founder to Herakleia in Trachisc.
Nauarch of the year 374/3. He was apparently despatched to Sicily and
on the way was supposed to ravage Corcyra. The attack miscarried.
Eusebius Chronicorum Libri II (ed. A. Schoene), I, 207, 208
Victor in the stadion during the 134th Olympiad
IG V 1. 770 (Ἀλκιλάδα ǀ Ἀλεξάνδρ[α]ς or Ἀλέξανδρ[ο]ς)
Twice brought offerings to Delphi, once under the archon Mnasimachos, again under Argillos 361/360.
Victor of the boys’ ke[lea] in the year of N— (1) and the year of
Hierothytes in the year of Aristokratid[as] (1)a
In 421 he took the oaths for the peace and the alliance with Athens
Husband of Damokrita, he was exiled from Sparta.
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)

Sphaireus in the year of [P. Aelius Alkandridas (2)]b

Prostat[es of the] city with M. Aurelius Nikephoros (9)a; epimeletes of the patronomia in the fifth year of the god Lykourgos (3)c; paid for two statues in honor of Pomponius Panthales (2) Diogenes Aristeasa
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

Poralla 67; Bergk Poetae Lyrici Graeci III p 46, fr 24a; Herakleides Pontikos II 2 in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, II p 210b; Suidas s. v.c; Anthologia Palatina VII 19, 709d; SEG XXIX 388 (S. E. Waywell, American Journal of Archaeology, 83 <1979>, 303, #49): mosaic portrait bust, associated with Sappho and Anacreone; Aelian varia historia XII 50; The Partheneion (D. L. Page), Oxford, 1951; Alcmani, I frammenti (Antonio Garzya), Naples, 1954; Antonio Farina, Studi sul Partenio di Alcmane, Naples, 1950; Athenaeus I 31cd, II 39a, III 81d, f, 110f, 111a, 114f, 115a, IV 140c, IX 373e, 374d, 390a, X 416cd, XI 498f-499a, XIII 600f, XIV 624b, [636d], 637a, 638e, 646a, 648b, XV 678c, 680f, 681a, XV 682a; Pausanias I 41.4, III 15.2, 3, 18.6, 26.2; Plutarch Lycurgus 28.10, Sulla 36.5, Moralia (de fortuna Romanorum) 318a, (de exilio 2) 599e, (quaestionum convivalium II 10.2) 659b, (de Herodoti malignitate 14) 857f, (aetia physica 24) 918a, (de facie in orbe lunae) 940a; Aristotle historia animalium 557a2; PW Supplement XI 19-29

The poet of Laconian choral lyric from the second half of the seventh century. Over his antecedents there is no agreement. (1) Alcman came from Sardisa. Added to that is the reference that Alcman was the slave of the Lacedaemonian Agesidasb. (2) Elsewherec the poet is described as Λάκων ἀπὸ Μεσσόας and is given Damas or Titaros as his father. (3) Alexander the Aetoliand takes a middle position in an epigram; he holds Alcman for a Laconian, but says that his ancestors came from Sardis. In a mosaic portrait bust Alcman was associated with Sappho and Anacreone.
Gerousias for the second time in the year of P. Mem(mius) Eudamos
Fell in 377 as polemarch in the army of Agesilaos before Thebes
He fell together with his brother Maron in 480 at Thermopylae and had a memorial in Sparta
Subject of an honorary decree as epi[tropos] of the emperors for his good will towards the Lacedaemonians
Son of Irbos and brother of Astrabakos.
He is supposed to have been the fourth descendant of Agis I.
Gr(ammateus) [of bidyoi (?) ἐπὶ .....o]υς (Fragment 128 = [Δαμοκλέο]υς, AD 132/3 or [Ἀριστοκράτο]υς, AD 150/1?)
In the summer of 424 he was sent from Sparta to assess the activities of Brasidas in Thrace.
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokrati-
AMMAIO[Σ], IG V 1. 40, error for [γρ]αμματόφυλαξ, see SEG XI 482
One of the five Spartan arbiters who awarded Salamis to the Athenians around 610

In 479 he fought in the battle of Plataea as leader of the Pitanatans and fell there, before he was 30 years old. His initial refusal to obey the command to retreat before the Persians brought on the battle. He was judged to be the bravest of the Spartans.
As ambassador to Argos shortly before 421 he tried to renew the thirty years truce
Poralla 75; Plutarch Alcibiades 1, Lycurgus 16, cf. Λανίκη
Bidyos in the year of D— (2)

An ephor, who, under the pretense of being a friend, lured Agis IV from his sanctuary, conducted him to prison, prosecuted and executed the king, the king’s mother, Agesistrata, and grandmother, Archidamia
The Oxyrhyncus Papyri, ed. Arthur S. Hunt, London, 1927, Part XVII, Number 2082; L. Moretti, Olympionikai, Lincei, 1955, page 133, number 515
He belongs, as do his descendants, to a fictitious series of Spartans who serve only to tie the Spartan hero Astrabakos to the royal line.
He belongs, as do his descendants, to a fictitious series of Spartans who serve only to tie the Spartan hero Astrabakos to the royal line.
Enseitos [in the year of Alk]astos (3), AD 136/7

IG V 1. 171 (Upon examination of the squeeze at the Prussian Academy I found no trace of a P, only scratches more like scars. The P I suspect is due to the too acute desire of the epigrapher to read traces; if this is a name, then it is AN—.)
Name (?) in a list in the year of P—
Eponymous patronomos in the year before Damarchos (3)
Daughter of the mythical king Thersandros of Kleonai, twin sister of Lathria
The pair were married to the sons of Aristodemos, Eurysthenes and Prokles.
King from the house of the Eurypontids
His reign falls at the turn of the seventh century.
Poralla 81; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.
King from the house of the Agids

In his first marriage he wed the daughter of his sister. Childless, he was compelled to take a second wife (the daugher of Prinetadas), by whom he had the later king Kleomenes I. By his first wife he then had Dorieus, Leonidas, and Kleombrotos.
Anaxandridas was the contemporary of Croesus and Ariston. He reigned from about 550-516.
Under him the long war with Tegea was ended.
Poralla 82; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 3.4-5, 14.4, IV 15ff
King from the house of the Agids
His wife’s name was Leandris. Pausanias puts him in the time of thesecond Messenian war.
He was a victor in the Olympic games (Olympiad 88 = 428 BC ?) with the four horse chariot where also his father’s father had won in the Pentathlon.
Around 351 as leader of a Spartan detachment he was captured by the allied Thebans and Argives near Telphusa
Poralla 86; Xenophon Anabasisa V 1.4, VI 1.16, VII 1.10-20 2.4-8;
In the spring of 400 he and his fleet were at Byzantium. He attempted to hinder the 10,000 from crossing into Europe (with one eye on the Persians)ac.
Around 389/8 he came to the Hellespont as harmost of Abydos. He was caught there by Iphicrates’ expedition to Abydos and fell in battleb.
Collateral relative of the house of the Eurypontids
According to the suspect list of Pausanias he was king at the end of the second Messenian war.
King from the house of the Eurypontids
He may have ruled about the middle of the seventh century.
He spoke as one of the five Spartan arbiters who awarded Salamis to

In winter 393/2 he travelled to Sardis to the satrap Tiribazos from whom he received money for support of the fleetd. As nauarch of the year 388/7 he sailed from Aigina to Ephesus and betook himself to the Great King with whom he worked out the terms of the peace named after himeg.
After that he relieved Nikolochos who had been shut up in Abydose.
At the time of the 371 peace conference in Sparta he was spending time at the court of the Persian kingf.
In 370/69 he held the office of ephorc.
It was probably in 367 that he travelled for the third time to the king. There, however, when his mission was fruitless, he committed suicidea.

A sufferer from dropsy. Her mother went to the shrine of Asclepius in Epidaurus to find a cure. In her sleep she saw Asclepius decapitate her daughter—a liquid flowed from her head—and he rejoined head and neck. The mother hurried home to Sparta, found her daughter cured, and the dream fulfilled.

A Lacedaemonian honored by Cotyrta for his benefactions. He and his descendants were granted the rights of proxenos and benefactor: to own land and a house, to contract marriage, to have the protection of law, exemption, asylum in war and peace, and the other customary rights.

Father of Akrotatos (2), king of Sparta

He succeeded to the throne despite the fact that Kleonymos (1), son of Kleomenes II, was alive. Kleonymos, however, was given command of the armies. Their rivalry, intensified, no doubt, by Akrotatos’ adultery with the wife of Kleonymos, led to Kleonymos’ leaving Sparta and joining Pyrrhus.bd
Areus was an active king, forming connections in Sicilyg, Creteei, Egyptjk, and possibly Judaeah.

He attempted to restore the Spartan hegemony of the Peloponnesus and opposed the Macedonian forces in Greece, although he was forced into a brief alliance with them to forestall the invasion of Pyrrhus into Laconiaf.
He was killed in an attempt to force the Macedonian lines at Corinth, 265 BCc

In SIG3 430 the Delphians grant proxenia to “King Areus, son of King Akrotatos and Queen Chilonis.” The editor believes that this refers to Areus I, since it seemed unlikely to him that the Delphians would grant proxenia to a child, albeit a king. Akrotatos, however, the father of Areus I, was not a king. There is but one king Akrotatos and he is the father of Areus II. Moreover, the Chilonis of the inscription might well be the widow of Kleonymus and lover of Akrotatos the king [26.17-18].)
He was born after the death of his father at Megalopolis, 262 BC. Leonidas (1), the son of Kleonymos (1), was regent. He was an Agiad king.
He died of disease when he was eight years old.
Livy XXXIX 35-37; Pausanias VII 9.2-4; Polybius XXII 1.9 & 11.7-12.4; XXIII 4.3
He was exiled from Sparta by Nabis and restored against the wishes of the government of Sparta by the Achaean league.
In 184 BC he was an envoy to the Romans and he denounced the Achaean league.

Belonged to the Spartan court of five men who sentenced the Plataeans to death in 427. In 396 he was sent as ambassador to Thebes.

Pausanias says that he was the father of the mother of Agesilaos, which is totally impossible (because of the dates). He may have been the father-in-law of Agesilaos, that is the father of Kleora. Or the name of the father of the mother of Agesilaus may have been Aristomenidas, but a different person. See Μελησιππίδας.

Priestess of Demeter in Laconian Aigila; she was supposed to have freed the imprisoned Aristomenes in the Second Messenian War
Mother of Agesistrata, Agesilaos (2), {and Archidamos (2) IV?}b

Grandmother of Agis (1) IV, Archidamos (3) <V>, and Hippomedon (1)a <Polybius (IV 35.13) states that Hippomedon was in the line of Eurypontid succession, which would be readily understandable if he were the grandson of a king. Agesilaos, his father, was the son of a Eudamidas. Eudamidas I was a Eurypontid. It seems likely then that Archidamia was the wife of Eudamidas I.>

During the invasion of Laconia by Pyrrhus, 272 BC, Archidamia opposed a plan to send the women and children of Sparta to Crete. She organized the women to fortify the city, carry weapons, and treat the wounded. She aided and encouraged the Spartan soldiers.c
She was one of the wealthiest women in Sparta, but she supported the reforms of Agis IV with both her money and her influence.a
She was executed after his fall in 241 BCb
Poralla 153; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 218b; Lycurgus 20
A Spartiate contemporary of Hecataeus (of Abdera?)—he responded to a criticism of Hecataeus and to a question about the number of Spartiates

According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house, son of Theopompos and father of Zeuxidamos. He is supposed to have died before his father. Perhaps to be identified with Archidamos (Poralla 154).
According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house and son of Anaxidamos and father of Agasikles

Poralla 157; Plutarch Agesilaus 1a, 2.6; Herodotus VI 71b; Xenophon Agesilaus 9.6c, Hellenica V 2.3d; Pausanias III 7.10e, 15.1f, VI 1.6g; Diodorus XI 63.4-64.1h, XII 42.6-8i, 47.1-2j; Thucydides II 10-12k, 18-23l, 47m, 71-78n, III 1o; Libanius declamationes 20.19; Athenaeus XIII 566a
King from the house of the Eurypontids
Father of Agis II (from his first marriage with his step-aunt Lampido)ab and Agesilaos II and Kyniska (by his second wife Eupolia)acfg

When shortly before 476 Leotychidas had to go into exile at Tegea, his grandson Archidamos assumed the rulee. Whether he had already taken part in the battles of Tegea in 473 and Dipaia can not be known. He was first mentioned in the great earthquake in Sparta in 464, where he saved the state through his presence of mindh. He distinguished himself in the ensuing battles against the Messeniansd.
Archidamos commanded the first invasion of Attica in the year 431 and 430klm. In 429 he took Plataea and in the next year led an army into Attica for the third time.no
He became sick and died at the latest in the Winter 427/6.

Poralla 158; SEG XI 457 (treaty with [Ach]aeans); Xenophon Hellenica V 4.25a, VI 4.18-19b, 26c, VII 1.28-32d, 4.20-25e, 5.12-13f; Plutarch Agis 3g, Agesilaus 19h, 33i, 34j, 40k; Camillus 19.8l; Pausanias III 10.3-5m, VI 4.9n; Arrian Anabasis II 13.6o; Isocrates Epistulae IX (Archidamos)p; Diodorus XVI 24q, 39r, 59s, 62-63, 88u; Aeschines II 133v; Athenaeus VII 289e, XII 536cd, XIII 591bw; Libanius orationes 64.83; declamationes (Archidami defensio) XXIV passim
King from the house of the Eurypontids (born about 400)
Son of Agesilaos II and Kleora.
Father of Agis III, Eudamidas I and Agesilaosgmo
In 371 he led the defeated army of Kleombrotos back from Megara to Sparta. (Diodorus XV 54-55 in error puts Archidamos also at the battle of Leuctra.)bc
In the years 367 and 364 Archidamos campaigned against the Arcadians in the fielddei.
Isokrates put a speech in his mouth that he was supposed to have delivered at the Peace Congress in Sparta in 366/5p.
In 362 he was occupied in the defense of Sparta against the Thebansfj.
After the death of Agesilaos II in the winter of 360/59 he ascended the thronek.

At the outbreak of the Sacred War Archidamos in secret helped the Phociansmq. Around 352 he fought against Megalopolisr, and in 346 led an army to help Phocis, but because of the ambiguities of the situation among the Phocian leaders returned to Sparta with nothing accomplishedsv.

After that he was sent to Italy to help Tarentum in a war against the Lucanians. He sailed first to Crete where he refounded Lyttos. In Italy he fought a battle at Mandonion 338—on the seventh of the month Metageitnionl—lost the battle and his lifegmtuv.
He had a portrait bust in Olympian and a statue in Delphiw.

He fought a battle with Demetrius near Mantinea, where he was defeated, 294 BCbc There is no further mention of Archidamos in the sources and he may have been killed in this battle.

Poralla 177; Thucydides II 25a, 85-94b, III 69c, 76-81d, IV 11-12e, 70-74f, 78-88g, 111-116h, 120-129i, 135j, V 2-3k, 6-11l; Aristotle Ethica Nicomachea V 10 p. 1134bm; Polyaenus I 38n; Plutarch Lycurgus 25o, Lysander 1, 18p, Nicias 9.3, Moralia (apophthegmata regum et imperatorum s. v. Augustus 14) 207fq, 79e, 240c, 343a,d, 347b, 349d, 400f, 401c, 548b; Pausanias III 14.1r; Libanius, ed. Foerster II 359,13s; orationes 18.281, 19.45, 64.10; Diodorus XII 43.2t, 62u; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10v; Chariton VIII 2.12; Aristophanes Wasps 475; Plato Symposium 221c; Lucian quomodo historia conscribenda sit 49; Isocrates orationes VI 53
In 431 he saved Methone from an Athenian attacka. He was the eponymous ephor of the year 431/30, though he was quite young (but still met the age qualification)tv.

In the next year under the command of Knemos he took part in the sea battle at Rhion and Naupaktos and in the attack on Salamisb. In the same duty he took part in 427 in the expedition against Corcyra of Alkidascd. In the battle at Pylos he distinguished himself and was badly woundedeu.

In the next year he gathered his forces in Corinth and Sicyon for the Thracian expedition and in Autumn 424 reached Thessaly. After a short march against the Lyncestan king Arrhabaios he turned himself to Chalcidice and brought over the wavering cities to his side. He fought from time to time with various fortune against Arrhadaios and the cities Potidaea and Torone, and in the second half of October 422 triumphed finally over Kleon in the decisive batttle at Amphipolis, but in it he, himself, was fatally woundedfghijkln. The citizens of Amphipolis buried him in the city and honored him as hero and founderlm.

In Sparta a cenotaph was erected for himr. Brasidas and the Acanthians had a common treasury in Delphip. Direct descendants of his are known from Augustan timesq. The heroism of Brasidas remained proverbial for a long times.

In 389/8 he was epistoleus of the nauarch Hierax; as such he was occupied in Aegina. From there he went with Antalkidas, the nauarch of the next year, to Ephesus and then travelled back to Aegina, where he defeated the Athenians at sea in a moonlit battle. Soon thereafter he fell into an ambush in Aegina (set by Chabrias) and was killed along with eight other Spartiates.

He was a mothaxa, that is, his father had lost his citizenship due to criminal acts and Gylippos, apparently, had entered the agoge sponsored by someone else.

When the Athenians lay siege to Syracuse during the Peloponnesian War, Gylippos was sent by the Spartans to help the Syracusans. He organized the defense, defeated and destroyed the Athenian forces.bce
After that Gylippos was sent back to Sparta by the Syracusans because of his greed and his imperiousness.f

We find him next in the fleet of Lysander. He was sent back to Sparta after the battle of Aegospotami with the valuable booty. Gylippos embezzled part of it, was caught and condemned to death and fled into exile.dg
He fought together with his six brothers at an unknown time against Messenia (thus after 369 BC) and was the only survivor.

After the death of his father Damaratos began his reign, at the latest in 510.c He was the only one of the Spartan kings to win the chariot race at Olympia, 504 BCeu
In spring of 506 he and Cleomenes I led an army against Athensf
Despite the sources he could hardly have taken part in the operation against Argos in 494.mp
As Kleomenes in 491 moved against Aegina, to seize the leaders of the party friendly to Persia, Damaratos chose, through his intrigue, to bring this maneuver to nothing.a
As revenge for that he was now driven from the throne by Kleomenes and Leotychidas, ca. 491.bcdq
Damaratos escaped from Sparta under the pretext of a trip to Delphi and fled through Elis and Zacynthos to the Persian king Darius.eg
In 480 he accompanied Xerxes on the expedition against Greece.hijklnr
As a reward for his valuable service he received the cities Teuthrania, Pergamon, Halisarna, and Gambreion after the invasion as his family possession.st

The inscriptions reads Δαμοκλῆς < Ἀρι—. If < were the patronymic, < = Δαμοκλέους, and Ἀρι—the grandfather, we would find it written (most likely) Δαμοκλῆς < τοῦ Ἀρι--. We may have an honorific title here, as ἀριστοπολιτεύτης, which certainly makes sense, given that his name appears on the base of four statues.

According to an inscription found in Sparta he and his horses had won victories at different contests. The letter forms seem to indicate the second half of the fifth century. The three ephors named in the inscription do not appear in the list of Xenophon (Hellenica II 3.10), so the inscription must be dated either before 433/2 or after 404/3. That they won over fifty victories, but none in Olympia (Pausanias VI 2.1-2: list of Lacedaemonian victors) suggests that their victories fell in the period when the Spartans were excluded from the Olympic games, 420 to 400 or 396 (Thucydides V 50; Xenophon Hellenica III 2.21; Pausanias VI 2.1-3) and that the named ephors held that office after 404/3. The letter forms are not decisive. (contra Moretti!)

Poralla 228; Plutarch Lycurgus 15; Thucydides VIII 61-62; Diodorus XIV 38, 39. 5-6; Athenaeus XI 500c; Oxyrhynchus Hellenica 21.2; Isocrates orationes IV 144
A Spartiate whose cleverness earned him the nickname Sisyphos
In 411 he betook himself to the Hellespont and we meet him there as harmost of Abydos in 407/6.

In 399 in Ephesos he took over the command of the war against Persia from Thibron and he held it three years. When Agesilaos took over his command he returned to Sparta in Spring 396. In late summer 394 he brought the news of the battle of Nemea to Agesilaos in Amphipolis and continued on to the Hellespont again where he saved Abydos and Sestos from the allied Athenians and Persians.
Lacedaemonian envoy to Pyrrhus during the invasion of the Peloponnesus, 272 BC
Slain by bandits on his way to Sparta
Mother of eight sons, all of whom were supposed to have died in battle
IG XI 4. 542 (= Félix Durrbach, Choix d'insciptions de Délos, Paris, 1921, I 15)

Subject of an honorary decree of Delos for the favor he and his father showed to the temple. Apparently he interceded with Lysimachus for Delos between the years 300 and 281 BC From the wording of the inscription it would appear that Gorgion had died by this time.

Demaratos is probably the descendant of the exiled king of Sparta, Damaratos, who lived in and possessed Pergamum, Teuthrania, and Halisarna in Mysia, and whose descendants continued to live in the area. If so, Demaratos had returned to Sparta by this time, perhaps at the request of Lysimachos in 295 BC
Demaratos may be an ancestor (grandfather?) of Nabis, whose father's name was Damaratos and who had connections with Delos.
His family belonged to the most illustrious in Sparta. Both of his granddaughters were married to kings and there appears to be a family connection with Chilon the Wise. (stemma)

Citizen of Sardis, Alexandria, Antinoopolis, Nicomedia, Tralleis, Ephesus, Smyrna, Miletus, Pergamum, Corinth, Athens, Argos, Delphi, Elis, and Lacedaemonabde

He was the victor in over one hundred contests, including victories in the Olympic games at Pisa, the Pythian at Delphi, the Isthmian, the Nemean, the Capitoline at Rome, and at Sparta the Eurycleian twice, the Uranian three times, and the Leonidean once. He won the victory games of M. Aurelius and Commodus and received a gold crown and a prize.de
He was named high priest and president of the athletic association of the Eurycleian games (and others) by M. Aurelius and Commodus.abe
He was named high priest and president of still other athletic associations by Severus and Caracalla.e
Hence, he was born before AD 160 and died after 212.
He was sent by Archidamus III after the “tearless battle” with news of the victory to Sparta

He was sent to the Hellespont as the successor of Pausanias, but was not recognized by the alliance. Since Pausanias, as Leotychidas and Eurybiades before him, in their position as Spartan nauarch exercised the command over the League fleet, so would Dorkis, the successor of Pausanias, be Spartan nauarch.

Son of king Anaxandridas and his first wife
Brother of Leonidas and Cleombrotus, half brother of Kleomenes I

After Kleomenes came to the throne he travelled with a few Spartiates (515 or 514) and founded a colony in the vicinity of the modern Tripolis. He was driven out by the Carthaginians and returned to Sparta. Next he sailed to Sicily and founded the colony Herakleia at Eryx, but was soon besieged by the allied Egestaeans and Phoenicians and he was killed with the greater part of his following.
He may have taken part in the destruction of Sybaris.

Poralla 283; Thucydides VIII 23; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.32, 6.26, 35-38, II 1.1-6, 10, 2.5, V 1.1-2, 13; Anabasis VII 1.12-20; Diodorus Siculus XIII 97.3, 100.5, 106; Pausanias VI 3.15, X 9.10; Lycurgus adversus Leocratem 70 confuses him with Eurybiades.

A Spartiate who especially distinguished himself in the naval campaigns. In 412 he was detached by the Nauarch Astychos to Lesbos. After that he was engaged as harmost of Thasos, from where he was driven out by the party hostile to Sparta in 410. In 406 we find him by the fleet of Kallikratidas. It fell to him after the catastrophe at Arginusae with the remains of the ships and the army to hold out in Chios until Lysander came with reinforcements in 405; and he probably did this as nauarch of the year 406/5.

After the battle at Aegospotami, in which he played a famous part, he was ordered to Thrace. In the year 400 we find him in Byzantium under the command of Anaxibios. Around 389 he was stationed at Aegina for a long time, from which he disturbed the Athenians. For his service he had the honor of a statue in the monument of Lysander at Delphi. He also had a statue at Ephesus.
From the family of the Heraclids

Son of Agis (1) IV and Agiatis

The circumstances of Eurydamidas are unclear, but he probably was king during the latter part of the reign of Leonidas (1) II and the early part of the reign of Kleomenes (1) III. Kleomenes III became his stepfather.

Certainly he had died by the time Kleomenes tried to recall Archidamos (3), the brother of Agis IV, to be king, ca. 227 BC, and it may have been the death of Eurydamidas which raised the necessity of placing a king on the Eurypontid throne. Kleomenes is said to have poisoned Eurydamidas.
Poralla 322; Africanus in Eusebius (Schoene) I 200; Olymp 80

Father of C. Julius Lakon (1)i, C. Julius Deximachos (1)k, and Lachares (2)j
M. Antonius executed his father for piracy. Eurykles commanded a ship, possibly a contingent of ships against Antonius at Actiumd.
He was granted Roman citizenship, the rule of Sparta, and the island of Cythera by Augustusfgn.
He visited the court of Herod, ca. 7 BC, where he used the king's family problems to enrich himself.ab

After his return to Greece he was exiled by Augustus for “having filled Achaea with unrest,” probably by attempting to assert Sparta's hegemony of the League of Free Laconia and the rest of the Peloponnesus. His family remained in Sparta and his son, Lakon, was eventually granted the same status as his fatheraeho.
After his death Eurykles was honored with a festival instituted at Gythium by AD 15lm.

The war against Tegea was supposed to have been fought under him. The date of his reign falls in the beginning of the sixth century.
From the noble family of the Cadmeian Argives he was supposed to have been one of the leaders in the First Messenian War.

A Spartiate who accompanied Dorieus on his expedition to Libya and Sicily. He saved himself and the survivors of the battle at Egesta in 510 and forced his way into Selinuntum and ruled there. After a short reign he was driven out and killed.

She won the four horse chariot race at Olympia and received a statue for it in Sparta. Kyniska the sister of Agesilaos was the first Greek woman (Pausanias III 8.1) allowed to compete with her horses, so the victory of Euryleonis must come later <Ol 103 = 368?>.
A Spartiate who in winter 426/5 sought to take Delphi from Naupaktos. After this miscarried he turned to Acarnania, were he fell in a battle at Olpai against the Athenian Demosthenes.

In the older sources he was the son of Prokles and in the later the son of Soos
Eurypon was supposed to have led a war against the Arcadians.

The first Spartan king from the house of the Agids. He is, like his brother, an invented person to explain the origin of the double kingship. The ancient chronographers gave him a reign of 42 years, 1103/2-1062/1
Collateral member of the house of the Agids
Descendant, perhaps grandson, of king Damaratus and brother of Prokles. In the year 399 we find both brothers as master over Pergamum, Teuthrania, and Halisarna.

Poralla 363; Herodotus VIII 131; Polyaenus VIII 34; Quintilian Instutiones oratoriae II 17.20; Pausanias III 7.5, 31-2, IV 7.7-9, 8.8-9, 15.3; Tyrtaeus 5, fragment 2 (Prato); Plutarch Agis 21, Lycurgus 6; Diodorus VII fr 8; Aristotle politica V p 1313a26; Valerius Maximus IV 1.8
Father of Anaxandridas (and, according to Pausanias, Archidamos)
His wife Chilonis (the daughter of Kleadas) was supposed to have saved him from imprisonment at the hands of the Arcadians.

Theopompos ruled contemporaneously with Polydoros at the time of the First Messenian War. Therefore his time is set in the second half of the eighth century. He was supposed to have entered his grey old age at the time of the battle of the Thyreatis.
He must also have played an important role in the inner politics, especially as the origination of the ephoria was attributed to him.

On the story of the capture and rescue of “Theopompos” neither Polyaenus (VIII 34) nor Quintilian (institutiones oratoriae II 17,20) indicate that this Theopompos is King Theopompos. Polyaenus is usually scrupulous about giving titles to his characters. I think that this is a case of a famous story (cf. Herodotus IV 146), not a famous individual, and the Theompompos here should be regarded as another Theopompos or as an individual of another name altogether whose deed was attached to a famous name.
As polemarch he was besieged by Pelopidas at Tegyra in 375, where he was killed.
"[Well born], from a youthful age [acting for the best politically], and for virtue"
An old man (“geron”) who cultivated the vines under Taygetus, watered by the Plataniste which produced the wine which the speaker (Theognis) drinks

A Spartiate who in the year 412 was sent by Agis II to the Corinthian Gulf to free the Lacedaemonian ships caught there
One of the companions of Dorieus who accompanied him on his expedition to Libya and Sicily and fell at his side in the battle against the Egestaeans and Phoenicians shortly after 510.
Philo[n—] (6) paid him a silver [min]a for the (manumission) of [M]eleion
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)
Θηρικίων, Poralla 367a; Michael Apost XV 13, cf. Θηρικύων
One of the early supporters of Kleomenes (1) III
He helped murder the ephors. After the battle of Sellasia he committed suicide. (Whether he was a mothax of Kleomenes III depends upon the deletion of kaiv from 8.1.)
Father of a ...ippos, who in the second half of the fourth century was a colleague of the Delphian finance officers of the naopoioi
On seeing the camp of Philip II at the Isthmus in 338/7, he said to a Corinthian, “The Peloponnesus has poor gatekeepers in us.”
Poralla 370; Xenophon Hellenica IV 8.29; Diodorus XIV 94.4
A Spartiate. Harmost of Methymna, was besieged by Thrasyboulos in 389 and killed.
He brought ships in 412 to the nauarch Astyochos in Asia Minor and concluded the second Lacedaemonian-Persian alliance with Tissaphernes in Miletus.
Drove the tyrant Neogenes from Hestiaea around 377.
A polemarch, who fell in the battle at the Piraeus in 403
Poralla 374; Xenophon Hellenica III 1.4-8, IV 8.17-19; Diodorus XIV 36-38, 99; Athenaeus XI 500c (Qivmbrwn)

Began in winter 400/399 the war in Asia Minor, but was soon relieved by Derkylidas and sent into exile. In 391 however he was trusted with the command in Asia Minor. After some initial results he was caught and killed by Struthas in the region of the Maeander. Although it is nowhere stated that Thibron is a Spartiate, his position of command requires it.
A writer who wrote about Lycurgus.
He is probably Lacedaemonian and perhaps can be identifed with the above.
Poralla 376; Arrian in Photios 92.16-19 in Dübner's edition of Arrian

The Laconian friend and commander of mercenaries of Harpalos. As this one in 324/3 fled from Athens to Crete, T. murdered him and took possession of his treasure. He sailed to Crete where in various battles he sought to establish some rule for himself, during which he found his death.
Θιοκλῆς, Poralla 376a; IG V 1. 457, cf. Θεοκλῆς (362)
Subject of a memorial by his wife
IG V 1. 20b; A. M. Woodward, BSA, XXVI (1925), 168, C6, C7
[Gerousias in the year of Menekles, AD 96/7]
IG V 1. 20b; A. M. Woodward, BSA, XXVI (1925), 168, C6, C7
Erected statues for his father-in-law, C. Julius Panthales, his daughter and
From Pitana, fell in an unknown time in a battle against the Argives

p.hi: Because he is not a famous name, perhaps he is a contemporary of Dioscurides, iii bc.

body.p: Victor of the boys' keloia in the year of Lakon (3)
[Dia]betes [voluntarily] in the year of Claudius [Atticus], AD 133/4
Commanded as nauarch in the year 426/25 the Spartan ships at Sphacteria
Gravemarker: married, survived by his children
A member of the pro-Macedonian faction in Sparta
Murdered by members of the pro-Aetolian faction
The date is defined by the ephor list of Xenophon (Hellenica II 3.10) which reaches to 404/3 and the death of Agis II which falls in the summer of the year 399.
Poralla 379a; in Etymologicum Magnum <T. Gaisford, Oxford 1848> s. v. Ἄκαρα—he is identified with Ἄθυμβρος. cf. Tümpel, RE, s. v. Athymbros
Opsopoios of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)
Poralla 380; Diodorus XIII 76.6, XIV 3.5; Xenophon Hellenica II 1.18-20, 28; Plutarch Lysander 9, 19
A Spartiate, commanded under Kallikratidas and Lysander in Asia Minor.
After the ravaging of Samos Plutarch names him the harmost. Soon thereafter he was sentenced to death by the ephors because money was found in his possession.
IG V 1. 258 (the restoration is based on the meter and the association with the name Teisamenos)
Poralla 381; D. L. Page, Alcman, the Partheneion, Oxford, 1951
One of the young women singers mentioned in Alcman's Parthenion
Ἱάρων, Poralla 381a; Inscriften von Olympia 274, cf. Ἱέρων
Retrograde inscription on a fragment of white marble found in Amyclae
Poralla 382; Plutarch Agesilaus 13 (Ἀδαῖος); Xenophon Hellenica IV 1.39
As the grapheus of Agesilaos II he was constantly at the king's side in the campaign in Asia Minor of 396-394
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)
As nauarch of the year 389/88 he sailed from Aegina to Rhodes, where he was relieved of his command by Antalkidas.
Gerousias in the year of Pratonikos Polykratous
Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)
Bidyos in the year of D— (2)
IG V 1. 20ba, 97b; SEG XI 564c; A. M. Woodward, BSA XXVI (1925), 168, C6, C7d

p.hi: <One of these is probably an inscriber's error, but it is also possible that we have here two individuals.>

[Gerousias in the year of Menekles]ad, AD 96/7
IG V 1. 20b, 97; SEG XI 564; A. M. Woodward, BSA XXVI (1925), 168, C6, C7
Poralla 384; Xenophon Hellenica VI 4.9; Plutarch Moralia (de Pythiae oraculis 8) 397e; Dittenberger-Purgold, Inscriften von Olympia 274; Pomtow, Klio IX 181-2
A Spartiate who commanded the mercenaries at Leuctra in 371 and there met his death. He had statues in Delphi and Olympia. The base of the latter is extant.
She and her husband paid for a memorial to their son.
Dedication prompted by a dream at the shrine of Asclepius at Epidaurus
Citizen of Smyrna, Alexandria, Athens, Lacedaemon, and Tralles
Palaistes, pankratiastes pleistoneikes paradoxos, pyktes aleiptes
Victor of the boys' pankration at the Pythian games
The city of Smyrna honored its own citizen for his victory in the third Uranian games (or for his third victory) in 109/110. Granted Spartan citizenship?
Rizakis 412 (C. Julius [Damocritus] D f.); IG V 1. 98
[Pre]sbys of [geront]es in the year of Mnason (7), AD 91/2-94/5
Gerousias (for the second time) in the year of Biadasb, AD 153/4
[Gerousias (for the third time)] in the year of [C]la[udius] Sejanusa, AD 154/5
[Synarch] of [P. Aelius Damokratidas (3)], cf. IG V. 1. 553
Rizakis 409; IG V 1. 158 (cf. SEG XI 631); SEG XI 542 (ΟΥΔΙΟΣ = [Ἰ]ού{λ}ιος or [Ἰ]ού(λιος) Δῖος?)
No[m]ophylax in the year of L. Vo[lusenus Ari]s{t}okrates (10), AD 100/1
Ἰούλι[ος] -- (12), IG V 1. 182, see Ἰούλιος Νέας
Ἰούλ[ιος] -- (13), IG V 1. 182, see Ἰούλιος Λῦκος (1)
Gero[usias in the year of L]ampis, AD 118/9 or 119/20
N[omophyl]ax in the year of Caes[ar], i. e. Hadrian, AD 123/4
(K[asen] to {Hie}ro{nym}os?, rejected in Rizakis, see Stromnoi)
Gerousias (?) in the year of Anonymus
Γ(άιος) Ἰούλιος Φάβια Εὐρυκλῆς (2) Ἥρκλανος Λ(ούκιος) Οὐιβούλιος Πεῖος
Γά(ιος) Ἰού(λιος) Λ— (3) or Γά(ιος) Ἰούλ(ιος) —
A Lacedaemonian living in Calamae, honored by the city of the Lac[ed]aemonians for his piety towards his parents, his moderation, and his learning
Grandfather of Chariteles (1) and Junius (1), a Lacedaemonian living in Calamae
The second officer of the Spartiates trapped on Sphacteria in 425
Subject of a decree of the city: "herois[sa]"
Gravemarker in the precinct of Athena Chalcioecus
Synarch of the patronomia with Kabonidas
Eponymous patronomos within a year or two after Euetes
Subject of honors for his good deeds by Ti. Claudius (9) .at.es and T. [Oc]tavius Lon[ginu]s (2)
Poralla 387; Diogenes Laertius VIII 84; Athenaeus I 14de; FGrH 589
Author of a constitution of the Laconians in five books

Was given the mission in 333 by Agis III to bring money and ships from the Persians to Cape Taenarum. He is not categorically stated to be Lacedaemonian but from the importance of the mission he certainly would be.
A close friend of Kleomenes (1) III
He accompanied the king to Alexandria after the battle of Sellasia and died in the abortive break-out, 219 BC
Poralla 389; Polyaenus II 15 (Ἱπποδάμας at "Prasiae"); Callisthenes in Athenaeus X 452a; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 222a

A Spartan army leader, who was besieged by the Arcadians in 364 in Kromnos. He appears around 352 in the struggle against Megalopolis and died at an age of 80 years (thus born in 432). The time of his death is established by Plutarch where king Archidamos and Agis were in the field together against Megalopolis. That was possible only in 352. He must have been a Spartiate since he fought in the immediate circle of the king.
Subject of an honorary decree by a foreign city for benefaction

Name of a Lacedaemonian in an inscription found in Thespiai. Dittenberger puts this inscription in the years 378-371 when a mora under the command of a polemarch was stationed in Thespiai (Xenophon Hellenica V 4.46)
Poralla 391; Thucydides VIII 35, 99, 107; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.23, 3.5-7; Diodorus XIII 66.2

A Spartiate who commanded in the Peloponnesian fleet after 412. 411/10 he held the position of epistoleus under the nauarch Mindaros. After that he was harmost of Chalcedon and found his death in the defense of this city in spring 409.
Father of Agesilaos and probably also of Agasikles
He reigned approximately in the beginning of the sixth century.
Poralla 393; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 222ab
A Spartan, who probably spend time in an official position in Asia Minor at the end of the fifth or beginning of the fourth century

Plutarch Agis 6.5a, 16.4-5b; Polybius IV 35.13c; IG XII 8. 156d; Teles (Hense 2) page 23, line 9e; Otto, RE XVI 1884-87 #14; Piero Treves, Euforione e la storia ellenistica, Milan, 1955, pp. 48-54 (poem title); B. A. v. Groningen, Euphorion, Amsterdam, 1977, pp. 91-96, ##30-32 (discussion of identification of H., p 96); Photius Bibliotheca 153
Once removed from the succession to the Eurypontid thronec
He went into exile with his father, ca. 241 BCb
He was the military and civilian governor of Ptolemy III in the Thraceward region, 229-223 BCde
He was still alive when Kleomenes III died in 219 BC
Paianias in the year of Nikok[le]s (7)
A polemarch who through his disobedience at the battle of Mantinea in 418 was exiled

He was an Olympic victor as the first in boxing of the boys (Ol 37 = 632) and five times in men's boxing (Ol. 39-43 = 624-608). According to Pausanias he was accorded the same honors as were paid to Poseidon in Sparta.
Lacedaemonian proxenos of Epidauria, ca. 225 BC
Father of the Lacedaemonian heroes Astrabakos and Alopekos
Poralla 397; Plutarch Agesilaus 34; Aelian de natura animalium VI 3, cf. j Isivda"
He distinguished himself before he was quite 20 years old during the defense of Sparta against the Thebans in 362. (See jIsivda")

A Spartan youth who was supposed to have saved Gytheion in 370/69 from the Thebans. "Isidas" is certainly to be identified with "Isadas" above, the son of Phoebidas. The passage in Polyaenus is only a doublet of Plutarch Agesilaus 34 and confuses the two Theban invasions of 370/69 and 362.
[Dia]betes in the year of Hermogenes (2), AD 118/9, 119/20, or 122/3
Ambassador to Hadrian at Nicopolis, AD 124/5
Dikastagogos from Asia in the year of Claudius Aristoteles (4), ca. AD 143-146/7
Gerousias in the year of Kleon (18), AD 147/8
Gynaikonomos in the year of Avidius Biadas, AD 153/4
Ergonas skanothekas in the year of Kallikrates (33)
A Spartiate who was sent to Brasidas in Thrace in 422

In 421 as one of the empowered representatives of Sparta he signed the peace of Nikias. Soon after that he travelled to Chalcidice. He must have returned quickly since he was one of the signers of the Spartan-Athenian alliance in 421.
Poralla 401; Diodorus XV 64.3-4 (Ἰσχόλας); Polyaenus II 22; Xenophon Hellenica VI 5.24-26
Fought in Thrace against Chabrias. This can ony have happened in 390/89 or 375, since only in these two years was Chabrias in Thrace.
In winter 370/69 he is found at the defense of Olos in the Skiritis and died there in a battle against the Arcadians
Father of Eupylidas, Eraton, Chairis, Lykos, Agis, Alexon, and Gylippos
All of his sons (except Gylippus) were supposed to have fallen before Messene (which was founded in 369)
Kleon Philotheou [kasen to, or synephebe of him?] in the year of Nike[phoros h]o [Markou]
Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of the eponymous office, at this date probably the eponymous patronomos
Poralla 402a; Photios lexicon s.v. Θουριομάντεις; Plutarch Nicias 5, cf. Κλεανδρίδας.
Father of Soter[icho]s (2), of the Limnaean obe

Took part in the army of Agesilaos II in Asia Minor and appears to have been a companion of Antalkidas in his peace embassy in 387.
Poralla 405; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.14; Aristole Athenaion Politeia 37/38; Plutarch Lysander 15; Libanius (ed. Foerster) VI 108.6
He was harmost with a garrison in Athens in 404/3
Gerousias in the year of Pratonikos Polykratous
Grammateus of the ephors (of the obe of the Amyclaeans)

Poralla 406; Athenaeus XI 782b; Aelian varia historia I 17; Galen protreptikos 9
An artist of Sparta from an unknown time; he worked in relief and miniature carving (such as a chariot and horses under the wing of a fly)
Fell at the battle of Plataea in 479, not yet thirty years old
Gerousias [for the second or more time] in the year of Nike[phoros h]o [Markou]
Presbys of the synarcheia in the year of Neikias (14), AD 141/2-6
Ambassador to Tarentum, for the execution of which office he was offered a large sum of money, which he refused, and major honors
IG V 1. 64a, 69 (of which [SEG XI 554] is a copy)b, 70c, 71d, 102e

Helped pay for an honorary stele to his father
Raised a memorial to her father
Poralla 408; Xenophon Hellenica I 6.1-33; Plutarch Lysander 6-7; Diodorus XIII 76-79, 97-99; Aelian varia historia XII 43; Philostratus Apollonius IV 32

Nauarch of the year 407/6. He took over the command in Spring 406 from Lysander. After a promising beginning, the invasion of Methymna and the victory at Mytilene, he was defeated by the Athenians at Arginusae and fell there. Aelian gives the information that K. was a μόθαξ. (Poralla suspects the truth of that assertion, particularly as he is linked with Lysander—“improbable”—and Gylippos—“false”—but, if a mothax does not have to be a helot, but could be the son of a disenfranchised citizen, then perhaps there is validity to these assertions.) Diodorus describes him as a Spartiate.
Poralla 409; Arrian Anabasis III 24.4; Curtius Rufus III 13.15
Spartan from a famous family. Ambassador to the court of the Persian king Darius III, after whose death he was captured by Alexander
Poralla 410; Stobaeus florilegium (ed. Meineke) III p. 140-144
A pythagorean of unknown time. There is a reference to his work περὶ οἰκίων εὐδαιμονίας.

A young man who in the first year of the reign of Agesilaos II was condemned to death for a plot against the Spartiates. K. belonged to the class of hypomeiones, as Xenophon excludes him from the class of homoioi. This only makes sense if K. belonged in the widest sense to the class of Spartiates.

Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος Αἴλιος Πρατόλαος (11) ὁ καὶ Δαμοκρατίδας
Father of Chilonis, the wife of king Theopompos

Poralla 420; Thucydides VI 93, 104; Plutarch Pericles 22, Nicias 5; Diodorus XIII 106.10; Suidas s. v. ἔφοροι and εἰς τὸ δέον; Polyaenus II 10; Strabo VI 264; Photius lexicon s. v. Θουριομάντεις (conjecture of Pappritz)
He may at some time (before 446) have conducted an operation against Tegea.

In 446 as ephor he accompanied the young king Pleistoanax on his operation against Athens. There, however, he accepted a bribe from Pericles to retreat, he was condemned to death, and he fled from Sparta. He travelled to Thurii (he may have been one of the oikists), obtained citizenship there, and fought as a general for his new fatherland against the Tarentines and Lucanians.
Poralla 421; Diodorus XV 54 (Λεανδρίας, Dindorf: Λεανδρίδας, C. Müller: Κλεανδρίδας)
A Spartiate in exile from Lacedaemon who fought on the side of the Thebans against his own country in 371

If Müller is right then we have here the son of Gylippos and grandson of the ephor Kleandridas, who both must have ended their lives in exile (and <ASB> perhaps one of the opponents of Agesilaus exiled by him)
Poralla 422; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v. Kallikratidas 1, 6) 222 bc; Xenophon Anabasis VI 4.18, 6.6-37, VII 2.5-6

As adviser to Kallikratidas in the fleet in 406 he advised Kallikratidas to accept 50 talents from the friends of Lysander to murder one of their opponents. (“If I were Kallikratidas, I would accept this offer.” “So would I, if I were Kleandros.”) In 400 he was harmost in Byzantium.

A Spartiate who fought in the battle at Amphipolis in 422. After the death of Brasidas he took over the command and led the troops back to the Peloponnesus.
Κλέαρχος, Poralla 424a; Diodorus XIII 108.10 in error for Κλεανδρίδας

Poralla 425; Thucydides VIII 8, 39, 80; Diodorus XIII 40.6, 51.1-6, 66.5-6, 98.1, XIV 12; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.35-36, 3.15-20; Anabasis I 1.9–II 6.5; Polyaenus II 2.6-10; Plutarch Artaxerxes 6, 18; Isocrates VIII 98; Ktesias in Photius (in Müller's edition of Herodotus p. 57/58); Athenaeus XI 505b; Lucian Gallus 25, dialogi mortuorum 14.2 (396)
He would have been born about 450.

From 412 he was busy in the Asia Minor theater of operations. He took part in the battle at Kyzikos. From there he was sent to Byzantium as harmost where he soon received the proxenia. There he made himself so hated that the Byzantines used one of his absences to confer with Pharnabazos in 409/8 to rebel. He fought at the battle of Arginusae with the nauarch Kallikratidas and after K’s death in the battle assumed the command and appears to have soon thereafter returned to Sparta. In 403 he was sent to help the Byzantines against the Thracians. He used the occasion to get revenge for their earlier revolt and acted as a tyrant. He was expelled by a Spartan army and he was condemned to death for disobedience and fled to Cyrus, who sent him with an army against the Thracians again. In 401 with the secret understanding of the Spartans he assumed command of the Greek mercenaries in the army of Cyrus, he was taken prisoner after the battle at Cynaxa by Tissaphernes, brought to Babylon and there executed.
Nomophylax in the year of Nikokrates (12), AD 86/7 or earlier

The youngest son of King Anaxandridas and his first wife
He was married to Alkathoa and had with her two sons, the later regent Pausanias and Nikomedes
As regent of his nephew Pleistarchos he commanded the Peloponnesian army at the Isthmus at the time of the battle of Salamis and died there shortly before the battle of Plataea.
King from the house of the Agids
Father of Agesipolis II and Kleomenes II
In 380 he followed his brother Agesipolis (I) to the throne.
In the beginning of 378 he led an expedition to Thebes to reinforce the occupation of the Cadmeia. In Spring 376 he tried to force the pass of Kithairon into Boeotia in vain.
In 374 for the first time he led an expedition into Phocis. In 371 he marched from Phocis and died in the battle at Leuctra on the 5th of August 371.
Plutarch Agis 11.7-9a, 16.6-18.4b; Pausanias III 6.7-8c; Polybius IV 35.10-12d; Strabo VIII 337e; Gerth, "Kleombrotos (4)," RE XXI 679
Of royal, Agiad, descenta, but Leonidas (1) in 254 BC "was the only adult male representative of the house of Eurysthenesc."
Agiad king of Sparta from the expulsion of Leonidas II to his return, at which time Kleombrotos was exiledab.
Either he or Kleonymos (1) founded Heraea in Arcadiae.
A Lacedaemonian occasional orator in Plutarch's essay
He was probably a student of the orator Aemilianus of Nicaea.
He travelled extensively in Egypt and he had sailed beyond the Persian Gulf.
He had sufficient money not to need to work.
He was compiling a history to serve as a basis for a philosophy the aim of which was theology.
Philippos (5) was ka(sen) to him in the year of Aristodamos (8).
Belonged to the college of arbiters of five Spartiates who in 610 awarded Salamis to Athens

Poralla 436; Herodotus V 39-41a, 48b, 61c, 64d, 65e, 66f, 70g, 72h, 73i, 74-75j, VI 61, 65-66, 73, 74-82k, VII 239l; Pausanias II 20.8-10m, III 3.10n, 4.5 (different versions of his death); Plutarch Moralia (mulierum virtutes 4) 245c-fo; Aristotle Athenaion Politeia 19p; Politica 1303a7; Aelian varia historia XII 8
King from the house of the Agids
Son of king Anaxandridas and his second wife
Half-brother of Dorieus, Leonidas, and Kleombrotosa

He had no male children, only a daughter Gorgo who was married to his half-brother Leonidasbl. After the death of his father he assumed the rule, probably shortly before 516abn. In Spring 510 he drove the Pisistratids from Athensdep. The second campaign against Cleisthenes, probably in Spring 507 miscarried in the face of Athenian opposition and the campaign of the next year through the intrigue of the Corinthians and his fellow king Damaratosghij. Around 494 Kleomenes undertook a very successful campaign against Argoskmo. Not long thereafter he moved against Aigina. Damaratos however foiled his plans. In revenge for this Kleomenes united with Leotychidas against Damaratos and with the bribing of the Pythia in Delphi they got Damaratos expelled from the thronecefi. When it later became known in what dishonest way Kleomenes had worked the downfall of Damaratos he was afraid of the consequences and he fled first to Thessaly and then returned to Arcadia where he attempted to form a League opposed to Spartak. From fear of the consequences the Spartans called him back and he set out on his former path. He died soon after, a terrible death, according to the Spartans in the throes of delirium tremens he committed suicide. The time of the death may be placed in 487.
Poralla 437; Pausanias I 13.4, III 6.2; Plutarch Agis 3, Moralia (Lacaenarum apophthegmata s. v. Gyrtias) 240ef; Diodorus XX 29; FDelph III 5.9I19 (336/5 BC)
King from the house of Agids
Son of Kleombrotos I and brother of Agesipolis II
His wife was probably the daughter of Gyrtias
After the death of Agesipolis II in 370 he took over the reign and ruled 60 years and 10 months, so to 309/8
Collateral relative of the Agid house
As regent for his nephew Pausanias he led the invasion of Attica in 427.

Plutarch Cleomenes; Agis 2.10; comparatio Agis Cleomenes Ti. Gracchus C. Gracchus; Philopoemen 5-6; Aratus 35-46; Moralia (quomodo adulator ab amico internoscatur) 53e, (de solertia animalium) 961b; Polybius I 13.5; II 45-71; III 16.3, 32.3; IV 1.8, 5.5, 6.5, 7.7, 9.4, 35.6-9, 37.6, 60.2, 65.5, 76.7, 81.2 & 14; V 9.8, 24.8, 34-39, 93.2; VIII 35.3; IX 18.1, 23.3, 29.8-10; XV 25.2; XVIII 53.1; XX 5.12, 6.8; XXXIX 8.5; Macrobius Saturnalia I 11.34; Pompeius Trogus prologi 28; Justin XXVIII 4.7; XXIX 1.6; Livy XXXIV 26.14, 28.1; XL 54.4; Athenaeus IV b-f; Pausanias II 9.1-3; III 6.9, 7.1, 10.7; IV 29.7, 9, 10; VII 7.3, 4; VIII 8.11, 27.15, 16, 28.7, 49.4-6; Lamprias Catalogue number 9; [Olympia 309]; [IG V 1. 458(?)]; Porphyrius de abstinentia (Nauck 213, 23ff) III 21; [Synesius peri basileias 28]; Themistius orationes VIII 115B; Cicero de natura deorum (Ax 146,5) III 65; Grunauer, pp. 113-116 (Gr. III-VII, Tafeln 1-4: portrait of the king); Th. Lenschau, "Kleomenes (6)," RE, XXI 702-10; F. W. Walbank, A Historical Commentary on Polybius, I (Oxford, 1970 <1957>), 272 on Polybius II 65
Son of Leonidas (1) II and Kratesikleia
Father of two children, one, at least, a boy, who died, 219 BC
Husband of Agiatis, the widow of Agis (1) IV

He carried through the reforms which Agis IV had conceived: cancellation of debt, redistribution of land, and enfranchisement, increasing thereby the strength of Sparta enough to regain the hegemony of the Peloponnesus.

Unlike Agis he did not draw back from violence against his fellow Spartiates. He had four ephors and a few of their adherents (whom he thought would oppose reform) murdered and he exiled about eighty more, although he held an allotment of land for them.
He persuaded Archidamos (3), brother of Agis IV, to return from Messene to Sparta to be king. Upon his return Archidamos was murdered.
He waged war against the Achaean League and all but destroyed it; he captured Argos.
Aratus induced the Macedonians to help the League and after two years of indecisive engagements Kleomenes was defeated at Sellasia, 222 BC
He escaped to Egypt and committed suicide in 219 BC (According to Polybius <XV 25.2> Sosibios, the treacherous regent of Ptolemy, instigated his "murder.")
Uncle of and regent to Agesipolis (2) III

Diodorus Siculus XX 104-105a; Frontinus Strategematica III 6.7; Plutarch Agis 3.4-8b, Demetrius 39.2-4c, Pyrrhus 26.14-27.10d; Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 219F, [233AB]e; Livy X 2f; Pompeius Trogus prologi 15g; Pausanias I 13.4-5; II 9.1; III 6.2-3h, 24.1i (—"Kleonymos son of Kleomenes son of Agesipolis," almost certainly an error for this Kleonymos, who was the son of Kleomenes and nephew of Agesipolis); IV 28.3j, 29.7; VII 7.3; [Teles (Hense, 1909) page 28, lines 10f]; Polyaenus II 29k; Parthenius 23l; Strabo VI 280, VIII 337; Athenaeus XIII 605Em; ICret xi 1n; Suidas s. v. Phylarchos; Th. Lenschau, "Kleonymos (3)," RE XXI 730-31
Father of Leonidas (1) II (born no later than ca. 300 BC)
Uncle and regent of Areus (1) I

When Kleomenes II died Kleonymos expected, inasmuch as Akrotatos was dead, that he would be chosen king. He was passed over in favor of his brother's son Areus, but he was [made regent] and given command of the armiesh.

Kleonymos, apparently, was a general of considerable ability. He aided Tarentum against the Lucanians in 309/8 BCa. He annexed Metapontumem and seized Corcyra, ca. 303 BCfg. He aided Boeotia against Demetriusc, ca. 293 BC, and seized Troezenk, ca. 279 BC He was engaged in operations against Messenej and Zaraxi; he mediated a truce in Crete between the Polyrhenians and Phalosarniansn.

The situation in Sparta became impossible for him after Areus I came of age and began to assert his rights. Areus' son was supposed to have committed adultery with Chilonis (but, as Leonidas, the son of Kleonymos, named his daughter Chilonis, the story may be considered suspect). Kleonymos left, joined Pyrrhus of Epirus, and accompanied him in an invasion of Laconiad.

Nauarch of the year 430/29, in 430 he ravaged Zacynthos. In the summer of the next year he invaded Acarnania and was defeated at Oiniadai. With Brasidas, who as miltary commander at Kyllene was attached to him, he tried to strike the Athenian Phormion at Naupactus but only suffered a new defeat. Again in late autumn of the same year his undertaking against the Piraeus was only partly successful.

Poralla 463; Pausanias II 19.7, III 21.1; Beendorf de anthol graec epigrammatis Bonn 1862 p. 13 (Argive); Anth Planud 54; Robert Hermes 35, 168 (to Oxyrhynchus Papyrus, ed. Grenfell-Hunt II p. 88ff = Ol 76 <476>); Catull. 58b.3; Juv. 13.97; Mart. Ep. 2.86.7f., 10.100.5f.; Rhet. Her. 4.4.14-21; Sen. Ep. 85.4.4f.; Solin. 1.96. (The Ladas of Pausanias III 21. 1 is a different individual and an Achaean.)

A runner famous for his speed who won the Olympic games in the diaulos. His grave was on the Eurotas (which is the reason for identifying him as Spartan). The speed of L. was proverbial even in the time of the empire. Ladas has the unusual distinction of being mentioned more often by Latin authors than by Greek. Myron (mid-fifth century) sculpted a statue of him. He had a statue in Argos. Ladas appears to be a nickname based on the meaning “a dappled deer.” (Hsch. 48, Lex. lambda 73.1 - ἔλαφος νεβρίας.
Grandfather of Chariteles (1) and Junius (1), a Lacedaemonian living in Calamae

He opposed Agesilaos II by revealing compromising letters found in the house of Lysander after he had been killed. The expression of Ephoros χρόνῳ ὕστερον suggests that some time must have passed between the death of Lysander and the ephoria of L.
He travelled to Sardis between 540 and 530 to warn Cyrus not to attack the Ionian states.

He was the ruler of Sparta from ca. 2 BC until exiled by Tiberiusab. He was reinstated by either Caligula or Claudiusdj.

During his exile he lived in Corinth. He was procurator of Ti. Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus; flamen Augusti, curio, agonothetes Isthmion and Caesarion, ca. AD 39, duovir quinquennalis, ca. AD 42, and augurd—or is this Lakon (2)?.

p.hi: He is a younger contemporary of P. Memmius Spartiatikos (6), ep. pat. 140’s. There is an obvious line of Memmii from Eurykles so a daughter of the family of Eurykles married into the Spartan Memmii.

body.p: A boy in 192 BC, he had been raised with the children of Nabis. After Nabis was murdered Laconicus was used as a rallying point in the uprising against the Aetolians.

The name Laconicus has been variously explained and emended as Laonicus, Leonidas (see Leonidas <2>), or as an ethnic, but in an age of such names as Nabis, Machanidas, Armenas, Lycurgus, Pelops, and Chilon, the name Laconicus may need no defense.

Olympic victor, Ol 85 = 440, with Veneti horsesb

Under the name Leon we find a tradition of different deeds. A Leon led out a colony in 426 as oikist to Herakleia in Tachiniac. Another was ambassador to Athens in 420 and eponymous ephor in 419/8df. Also it was a Leon who in 411 took over the command of the fallen Pedaritos in Chiose. Also the father of the well-known Antalkidas and of Pedaritos was named Leoneg.

The question is whether we should attribute all these notices to one Leon or whether we are dealing with different individuals of the same name. If Preger (Theodor Christoph Preger, Inscriptiones Graecae metricae: ex scriptoribus praeter Anthologiam collectae, <Leipzig, 1891> Chicago, 1977) n. 128 with his emendation is right and Leon won in 440 with the horses of his father, the reason may have been that he was too young to compete with his own horses; we could think of Leon as 20-25 years old then, when he won the Olympic victory, so that it would be possible that Leon had a son Pedaritos who in 411 must have been already 30 years old and that his second son Antalkidas in 393 already was in his maturity as he must have been to be an ambassador. So must Leon in 411 have been about 50-55 years old, old enough to have carried out an important diplomatic mission with Lichas and yet not too old to have taken the command of his fallen son Pedaritos. So Poralla proposes the following stemma
Gravemarker: three years old at death

After the death of Kleomenes I he accepted the rule about 487. In 480 he found a hero's death at the defense of Thermopylae. His bones were brought back forty years later from Thermopylae to Sparta. In his honor yearly games were held at his grave.

From his first marriage came a son Zeuxidamos. After this son’s early death L. married Eurydame and had a single daughter Lampito.
In 491 he united with Kleomenes to drive out Damaratus and become king in his place.
He helped Kleomenes in his scheme to take hostages among the Aeginetans; later, after the death of Kleomenes, he made a trip to Athens and asked that the hostages be returned to Aegina.
In Spring 479 he sailed past Delos to Asia Minor and defeated the Persian fleet at Mykale.
In 476 he led an army against the Aleuadae in Thessaly but took a bribe to retreat. In the ensuing outcry he betook himself into exile in Tegea, where he remained until his death in 469.
